questions.question: In what ways did sugar plantations not change life in the Americas, in Europe, and in Africa?

choices.answer: Europeans started to eat more candies.
Cane was easily broken by hand, though the climate was hot.
Natives were enslaved by Europeans before Africans.
Sugar plantations were the 1st plantations in the New World.

questions.question: Named after Christopher Columbus, the Columbian Exchange describes the broad exchange of:

choices.answer: Renaissance-era art during the "Roaring 1920s" in America.
coffee beans discovered by Juan Valdez in Columbia.
agricultural items, etc., between Europeans and Natives.
South American nations' monies throughout the world.

questions.question: All of the following was brought to the Americas by Europeans except:

choices.answer: Horses
Chocolate
Pigs
Rice
the acts of planting crops by the Native Americans.
handstands as part of tribal rituals in pre-colonized NC.
farms designed to grow crops on a large scale.
small fields dedicated to sustenance farming.

questions.question: The African Manikongo, like most African leaders, did not sell his own people. Instead, he:

choices.answer: killed Europeans who tried to buy slaves.
traded sugar for shell money.
built ships for Europeans to sail to India.
allowed travel to markets where Africans could be bought.

questions.question: England planned to settle in the New World for all of the following reasons except:

choices.answer: They were envious of the wealth Spain was finding there.
England was granted power by the Pope to do so.
It was a small island, running out of space for citizens.
England could use bases there to monitor Spanish ships.
the first English endeavor to settle in the New World.
the deck chairs on the Tyger.
the first English futbol (soccer) team for Queen Elizabeth.
The first successful settlement in Jamestown.

questions.question: Exploring the New World for Sir Raleigh, Barlowe and Amadas arrived at Roanoke Island on:

choices.answer: December 25, 1584
June 4, 1584
July 4, 1492
July 4, 1584

questions.question: At first, Chief Wingina saw the English as:

choices.answer: a terrible threat to Native American culture.
clean and sophisticated individuals.
potential allies.
potential help in growing corn before the harvest.

questions.question: Thomas Hariot did all of the following except:

choices.answer: created detailed drawings of Native American life
devoted his life to experiments and discoveries
studied math and astronomy at Oxford
described Roanokeâ€™s plants, animals, and humans

questions.question: On the second attempt to settle the New World, the English sent the following people except:

choices.answer: Manteo and Wanchese, returning after a year in England
Colonists who were farmers and family members
Thomas Hariot, to study the land and people
Artist John White, to draw the land and people
an unfair feeling of superiority toward a specific group
a list of perspective locations for settlement
a document granting someone permission to organize a colony
a laminated map detailing the sailing routes of explorers
